newsitem.title: USA: Democrats hope to reclaim Rostenkowski seat.
newsitem.headline: Democrats hope to reclaim Rostenkowski seat.

text.p: Republicans scored one of their biggest victories in the 1994 congressional elections in the heart of Chicago by knocking off legendary Democratic House power broker Dan Rostenkowski.

Two years later, "Rosty" is in jail for corruption but the Democrats seem likely to recapture his old seat. The reason: Rostenkowski's Republican successor Michael Flanagan let himself become too closely associated with an agenda that is widely unpopular among voters in his heavily urban district.

Rod Blagojevich, a 39-year-old Illinois state legislator who has the support of the remnants of Chicago's Democratic political machine, said his internal polls showed him leading Flanagan -- figures disputed by the Flanagan campaign.

"It feels really good out there," Blagojevich said. He said his optimism stemmed in part from animosity toward House Speaker Newt Gingrich in a diverse district spread across heavily Democratic Chicago.
"Flanagan has had an opportunity on a host of issues to vote his district but has chosen instead to vote to become a fellow traveller in the Gingrich revolution," Blagojevich said.

"I'm running against Mike Flanagan, not Newt Gingrich. I have to make sure I make that clear," he said. "But Flanagan supports Gingrich for speaker, which sets in motion a whole agenda that Gingrich has driven which has been harmful to working middle-income families in our neighbourhoods."

A recent Democratic-sponsored poll showed Blagojevich had overtaken the incumbent by eight percentage points among likely Fifth Congressional District voters. The poll had an error margin of 4.4 percent. A poll paid for by Flanagan showed the Republican leading by a similar margin.
The election in this Chicago district is one of 50 or so that could decide which party gets majority control of the 435-member House of Representatives. And the incumbent has become the underdog.

"To be within striking distance against one of the most formidable political armies ever assembled in Chicago, that's pretty good," Flanagan's campaign manager, Thom Serafin, said. He said he expected to be far outspent by the Democratic challenger, whom he called a "mini-Bill Clinton" for his campaign skills and alleged legislative failures.

Blagojevich said he would run strongest in the working-class "bungalow belt" of the Northwest Side and among lakefront yuppies, while suburban precincts will be "a challenge." One-quarter of the district's residents are foreign-born, and German, Polish and Hungarian are spoken in some neighbourhoods.

In 1994 Flanagan, an unknown lawyer with a no political track record, was viewed as the accidental beneficiary of Rostenkowski's legal troubles, which have since landed the 36-year congressman in prison. The onetime chairman of the powerful House Ways and Means Committee was sentenced to 17 months in prison after a plea bargain on charges he misused campaign funds and hired ghost payrollers.
"We think (Flanagan's) campaign was more of a stealth candidacy -- sort of hide in the basement and wait for people to vote against Rostenkowski," Blagojevich said.

Rostenkowski was renowned for securing federal money and tax breaks for local projects and Flanagan has suprised some by using his relationship with Gingrich and his cachet as a rare Republican representing a largely urban district to win millions of federal dollars to help rebuild Chicago's crumbling lakefront and public transit system.
But as one of Rostenkowski's most strident critics, he has had to defend the newly acquired federal largess as "good projects, not pork."

Blagojevich counters that Flanagan has a minuscule record, which includes a recent bill to confer honorary citizenship on Mother Teresa, that is out of step with his middle-class constituents. "He thinks big government ought to be there to help big corporate special interests," he said.
